column1: Tomatoes were supposedly a plant known to the Hobbits.
They were referenced in the first edition of The Hobbit
column3: p. 34 but J.R.R. Tolkien changed this to "pickles" in the third edition (1966).
column5: p. 43  The most usual explanation for the change is that the American plant-life would not fit in his setting of ancient Middle-earth.  However
column6: as pointed out by John D. Rateliff
column7: it may have been simply that Tolkien felt that it was too early in the year for tomatoes and substituted a preserved food instead.
